Award.AwardTitle: Enhancing the NMR Characterization of Amino Sugars
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this award, funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Cynthia Larive of the University of California - Riverside and her graduate student researchers will be supported to develop instrumentation for coupling online microcoil nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) detection with electrophoretic separation. The group will investigate the structure of the biologically important glycosaminoglycan (GAG) carbohydrate with two-dimensional NMR methods.

Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy is an important physical chemical method that gives precise chemical and structural information. The methods that Prof. Larive and her student researchers will develop will enable scientists to determine the solution-phase structures of some important carbohydrates. The work has the potential to provide important information on the biosynthesis of these carbohydrates, as well as guiding scientists in the design of new drugs and measurements of purity of related GAG-based pharmaceuticals (e.g. heparin). The graduate students working on this project will gain useful experience in developing cutting-edge analytical NMR experiments. As part of this work, Prof. Larive will continue her strong efforts at encouraging students from underrepresented groups to pursue careers in the sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The elegant structures of proteins and DNA provide beautiful examples of how a linear molecular sequence can create beautiful and functional three-dimensional scaffolds stabilized by hydrogen bonds and salt bridges. Though carbohydrates are also critically important biopolymers, much less is known about the relationship between their primary sequence and three-dimensional structures. This is especially true for the class of carbohydrates known as the glycosaminoglycans, which have a high degree of structural sequence diversity that enables these linear biopolymers to mediate a wide range of biological functions in health and disease. For example, heparin is a $5 billion drug used for treatment of thrombosis that is also implicated in cell differentiation, cancer and viral infections, and chondroitin sulfate is an important structural component of cartilage that is widely used as a dietary supplement for osteoarthritis. The goal of our research is to provide molecular-level insights that allow a deeper understanding of the relationships between carbohydrate primary sequence and the hydrogen bonds and salt bridges that create elements of localized secondary structure.

Intellectual Merit. This project enhanced our ability to detect and characterize the exchangeable NH and OH protons of glycosaminoglycan oligosaccharides. The work accomplished through this grant led to refined experimental protocols that provide more robust and reliable experimental signatures of hydrogen bond participation in GAG oligosaccharides derived from heparin and chondroitin sulfate. These experimental methods allowed the exploration of how local structure affects the properties of sugar amine groups and their participation in hydrogen bonds and salt bridges.  The results of this research have the potential to affect a paradigm shift in our understanding of the “glycan code” that relates the primary sequence of carbohydrates to their secondary structure and biological activity through protein binding.  As methods for the chemical and chemoenzymatic synthesis of glycans continue to improve, knowledge of the effect of primary sequence on elements of secondary structure like hydrogen bonds or salt bridges will become even more important as scientists gain the ability to create custom chemical scaffolds with unprecedented biological properties. 

Broader Impacts. The University of California-Riverside is a research-intensive Hispanic-serving institution with a highly diverse student body. In addition to this ethnic diversity, the University of California-Riverside educates more Pell-grant eligible students than any other research university, and takes great pride in graduating these students at rates similar to those of students from more affluent backgrounds.  A key component of this success is the early engagement of undergraduate students in research projects, such as this one, to retain them in STEM majors and provide the skills they need for a successful career.  For the undergraduate and graduate students participating in the proposed research, this project offers a unique interdisciplinary educational experience providing training at the interface of instrumentation, analytical chemistry, NMR and glycobiology; skills that are highly valued in the marketplace and important for the U.S. scientific enterprise.
